Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: An Accurate and Accessible Indoor Positioning Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is centered around the ability to potentially reinvent interactions with indoor spaces. Similar to how GPS has revolutionized how we explore the world outdoors, indoor positioning can augment indoor experience with new information; having impact through the whole chain from end users to the surrounding industries. For example, the ability to track critical equipment indoors can save lives as in the hospital ER, understanding the flow of people inside of buildings can optimize our approach to energy management, and the availability of precise navigation indoors can be used by both humans and robots to streamline factory and warehouse operations. Commercially, the opportunity for this technology is significant. The general indoor positioning market is estimate to grow 42% annually to $10 billion by 2018. Today's indoor positioning solutions remain imprecise and/or too cumbersome to deploy - diluting their commercial and societal impact to date. This technology fills a crucial gap in this space by providing indoor positioning that is at the same time accurate, compatible with today's devices, and easy to deploy.

This I-Corps project concerns an indoor positioning platform that is accurate, compatible with any Wi-Fi enabled user device (smartphones, tablets), and easily deployable. Research in this area has led to the development of hardware and algorithms that allow for sub-meter position accuracy indoors via easily manufactured compact Wi-Fi nodes built from commodity hardware. Simply placing these nodes at known locations in any indoor space allows for immediate positioning of user devices without additional pre-deployment effort. While GPS has revolutionized outdoor positioning, it does not work indoors. Current non-GPS solutions to this problem compromise accuracy, or require expensive hardware or calibration in the environment. This solution is both easy to deploy and accurate, filling an important gap in the indoor positioning industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps project explores the commercialization potential of an emerging technology, Ubiety, in the robotics and indoor localization space. The intellectual merit of this project includes development of, and understanding of, the commercial opportunities of an indoor positioning platform that is accurate, compatible with any Wi-Fi enabled user device (smartphones, tablets), and easily deployable.

Significant results include identification of customer segments, discovery of several pivots necessary to target these segments, and identification of a value proposition for these customer segments. Currently the discovered value proposition is in being able to provide low-installation overhead (6X less equipment than current competitors in U.S. hospitals) allowing Ubiety to be installed quickly and efficiently. Ubiety is able to provide sub-room accuracy, allowing for tracking interactions both inside/outside of patient rooms in the hospital market.

The project has provided many opportunities for training and professional development: from the initial intensive three-day workshop at the University of Michigan node, to one-on-one weekly office hours with the course instructors, and various conferences and workshops. Conferences attended by the team include emergency medicine conference ACEP16, future healthcare technologies conference MGMA, the Partners Connected Health Symposium, and the Department of Homeland Security Travel Initiative conference. In addition, individual meetings were conducted with emergency doctors, nurses, COO, CTO, surgeons, biomedical engineers, VP of technology development, and founders of several hospitals and health startups. Hospitals visited included Johns Hopkins, MGH, Beth Israel, Brigham and Women’s, Wake Forest Baptist Hospital, Stanford Hospital, UCSF medical center, NY Presbytarian, Cedar Rapids hospital. Companies that the team interviewed included WeWorks, Rifiniti, CISCO, Vocera, United, JetBlue, and many others.

The broader impacts of this work include: 1) dissemination of the learnings, and 2) increased potential for impact in the healthcare sector of accurate indoor positioning technologies for enhanced patient throughput.  The learnings of this I-Corps project have been disseminated through presentations at IdeaStream, the MIT Enterprise Forum, Robot Communication in the Wild workshop, HKN UROP event, and local talks including a local Massachusetts high school. In total, the team executed upwards of 150 interviews with varying levels of decision makers and stake holders in the target market of midsize to large hospitals. The team’s involvement in I-Corps and the learning from I-Corps lead to the development of two MIT UROP positions. (Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program). As a result, the learnings from I-Corps have been passed on to MIT undergraduate students who are conducting research on the Ubiety platform that is driven by customer input from I-Corps.

Through i-Corps, the team was able to identify real problems in the hospital market that could benefit greatly from an effective Real-Time Localization System (RTLS). In particular, the team discovered that hospital efficiency has been greatly challenged by overhauls in the health system and healthcare reform coming from the highest levels of government. This was a discovery made through in-person interviews. Additionally, it was discovered that hospitals view RTLS as a critical piece in managing their efficiency problems. Much like the adage, “you can’t manage what you can’t measure”, hospitals are struggling to precisely identify where their inefficiencies are manifesting.

From participation in I-Corps the team has a better understanding of what capabilities should be demonstrated by their technology in order to license to larger companies and/or displace incumbent technologies. The team EL, Stephanie Gil, has recently transitioned to a faculty position at Arizona State University in January 2018 where she will incorporate the evidence-based reasoning approaches that she learned in I-Corps to teaching students how to be involved in effective research. 

Currently the project is on-going.  The team’s most recent pivot is towards application to the robotics space where tracking of an autonomous robotic platform can assist with indoor navigation for patients, or shuttling of medications to patient areas.  


Last Modified: 09/23/2018
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky
